sections: Due to the stock market downturn, public pensions invested in private equity are about to face a reckoning ‚Äî but thanks to lax transparency regulations, pension members have no way of knowing how bad it might get. Matthew Cunningham-Cook takes a closer look in
, our extended weekly podcast for supporting subscribers, David Sirota interviews journalist and author Joshua Frank about his new book
Atomic Days: The Untold Story of the Most Toxic Place in America
, about the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Washington state.

Americans have invested $1.3 trillion in high-risk, high-fee ‚Äúalternative‚Äù investments like private equity, hedge funds, and private real estate that have been wracked with corruption scandals and financial misconduct. Those pension funds could soon face a reckoning, as the downturn in the stock market spreads to these alternative investments, resulting in costly reductions of their estimated value and in turn, increased contributions from state and local governments to meet those losses.

But most public pension members and beneficiaries have no way of knowing the extent of distress facing their investments. That‚Äôs because public pension funds rely on valuations provided by the managers themselves ‚Äî and thanks to secret contract clauses, managers can

‚ÄúAlternative investments give pension funds the opportunity to hide their losses, which means that they are made to order for this contractionary environment,‚Äù said Ted Siedle, a former attorney with the Securities and Exchange Commission who now represents financial industry whistleblowers. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a perfect place to hide. It‚Äôs no surprise that the increase in private equity and alternative investments was accompanied by an increase in secrecy. The bottom line is nobody knows what these investments are, nobody knows how they are performing, or what they are worth.‚Äù
As of publication, the main stock market index is down 17.4 percent since January, the longest period of falling stock prices since the 2008 financial crisis.

Public pension deals in the alternative space are notoriously opaque, with no full public disclosure of the underlying investments and accompanying contracts, the amount of debt or risk that a fund has taken on, the total fees paid to the firms involved, or the underlying performance and cash-flow data of these investments.
This is in stark contrast to investments in publicly traded companies, which disclose a wide range of information about their finances and face penalties for misrepresentation.

‚ÄúIn a general way, the whole [alternative investment] industry has been running on autopilot for the last 15 years with almost zero regulation,‚Äù said Jeff Hooke, a retired investment banker who now lectures on finance at Johns Hopkins University. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no cop on the beat. There‚Äôs no sheriff in town. They‚Äôve been able to report, without too much scrutiny, these glowing returns.‚Äù

Private equity and other alternative investments were originally peddled as vehicles that could deliver higher returns to investors, no matter the market environment, by taking over and transforming companies ‚Äî often by loading them up with debt and laying off workers.

Such promises helped inspire public pensions to enter the space. Forty years ago, most public pension funds didn‚Äôt invest in private equity or hedge funds at all, instead pursuing far more orthodox investments in stocks and bonds. Now, public pensions have more than a trillion dollars invested in alternatives.

Now, the repercussions of the industry‚Äôs overly optimistic forecasts are starting to be felt, as their portfolios‚Äô performance begins to reflect the economic downturn.

valuation process, as opposed to fair market value, or what it
worth if the pension fund tried to sell it on the open market.

said that the CalPERS writedown is indicative of broader problems in the industry. ‚ÄúA lot of the info you‚Äôre getting from the fund managers have a lot of guesstimates in it,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúPublic markets have been declining since January. The industry wants to make the case that they don‚Äôt decline like that, that they are way less volatile.‚Äù

Appelbaum, for one, isn‚Äôt buying it. ‚ÄúThe official private equity returns at the end of the second quarter were down 4 percent,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúPublic equities are down 18 percent and private equity down 4 percent? It‚Äôs just not believable.‚Äù

The alternative investment industry is built on a lack of transparency. The risks inherent in the space mean that managers have great incentive to create rosier returns. Poor return numbers make it harder to raise money for new investments. It‚Äôs why investment managers work to shield information about themselves and their activities from public view, so they are free to peddle stories of outsized returns with no accountability.
Now, that same secrecy will keep the true dangers currently facing these investments from going public.

To this day, only a small handful of contracts between alternative investment managers and public pension funds have been released to the public, and none of the raw performance data from these investments have been disclosed.

of the managers‚Äô fiduciary duty to the pension, which limits the firms‚Äô legal obligation to act in the pension‚Äôs best interest. Contracts also include provisions requiring binding arbitration for any disputes, eliminating the ability of pensions to seek redress in the courts.
